subSections.title: Definitions
Usage notes
subSections.text:
{{m|zh|點}} is often used for "o'clock", following the numbered hour: ''e.g.'' "three o'clock" is {{m|zh|三點}}. {{m|zh|點鐘}} would be used in the expression "1 o'clock" or "2 o'clock", in order to avoid confusion between {{m|zh|一點}} (meaning: "a bit") and {{m|zh|一點}} (meaning: "1 o'clock"). When spoken out, {{m|zh|一點}} (meaning: "1 o'clock") is usually pronounced ''yī diǎn'', without the tone sandhi, while {{m|zh|一點}} (meaning: "a bit") follows the sandhi rule.

When followed by the minutes, {{m|zh|點}} is used instead of {{m|zh|點鐘}} as in {{m|zh|[[十二]][[點]][[三十]][[分]]}}. In formal expression (but not in everyday speech), {{m|zh|時}} is used to denote hours, eg. {{m|zh|[[十二]][[時]][[三十]][[分]]}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
Fusion of {{ltc-l|底物}}, literally “what thing” ({{zh-ref|Guo, 2003}}).

Often related to {{zh-l|怎|tr=zam2}} due to similar syllable structure.
